messageBody:
On Feb 4, 2008 12:48 PM, Hobbs, Joseph <Joseph.Hobbs@...> wrote:
>
> Does anyone have any recommendations on how they arrange/group their
> jUnit tests? I've poked around the net but haven't gotten much in this
> category...

Try the JUnit FAQ. This entry might be a good place to start:

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#tests_15

There are many good pieces of information in the FAQ and I suggest
reading it carefully.

> The root of my question is simple... Should there be one large 'test'
> for each method or one small 'test' for each method possibility?
>
> To explain what I'm asking I have a short example... Assume the
> following method I'd like to test:
>
> int ReportManager.createReport(Report report)
>
> In this particular case, assume I'd like to test the following
> circumstances...
>
> * Does it throw an exception if report == null?
> * Does it throw an exception if report is empty?
> * Does it throw an exception if report is duplicate?
> * Does it return a valid ID if successful?
>
> So given this scenario, how would you do it? Would you go 'one big
> test', or '4 small tests'?
>
> 1 Test => testCreateReport
> 4 Tests => testCreateReportNull
> testCreateReportEmpty
> testCreateReportDuplicate
> testCreateReportSuccess
>
> I could see benefits going either way here. While 1 test would give you
> a 'hey this method is broken', and your resulting fail would tell you
> why (assuming your comment were appropriate). On the flip side, having
> 4 tests is just as easy since you'd see that single test fail.
>
> Comments? Thanks!

The best thing with JUnit testing is to think in terms of behaviours.
What behaviour are you expecting from your system and write a test for
that. Do not let the fact that some behaviours span multiple objects
while others use only a single method cause you to lose sight of the
fact that testing is best done at the unit level and the most workable
unit is the unit of behaviour.

That's what I do anyway. :-)

Simon
